Constitutionally, it is the Commonwealth's right to do so, and there has been the relatively recent example of the Commonwealth overriding Tasmanian law. Quite frankly, while legal opinion and constitutional rights have some place in this debate, so also does the very simple proposition that a small percentage of the Australian population should not set the standard for the rest of Australia on an issue of such importance as euthanasia.

To put the issue in perspective, there are 98,000 people on the territorial electoral roll, and that figure is somewhere between a good test match crowd and an Australian Rules football crowd at the Melbourne Cricket Ground. It is 15,000 more than the number of people who make up the federal electorate of Adelaide. I am sure that my constituents would not regard it as their prerogative to make decisions for the rest of Australia. It is right and proper that this debate is taking place at a national level.

Australia has already decided that the potential of having even one innocent person being mistakenly put to death outweighs the arguments for capital punishment. As a matter of moral consistency, Australians should oppose euthanasia. `The possibility of even one patient being euthanased as a result of a wrong diagnosis or administrative mistake,' writes one doctor to me, `is too horrendous to even consider.' I agree with him.

It is to be expected that there will be different and strong views expressed in this debate, but little is to be gained by those who oppose the bill seeking to put those of us who support the bill into various boxes or categories. It is entirely natural and reasonable that our life experiences will shape our opinion and thus the decision we reach. Therefore, it does not surprise me that the government members and senators who in previous occupations were doctors or nurses oppose euthanasia and support this bill.

I was trained to be a healer and a carer, and I know that it is quite wrong to argue that to legalise euthanasia is the only way to ensure death with dignity. As one commentator put it, `In any other context it would be regarded as a nonsense to propose death as a proper solution for difficult human problems.'

There is a natural instinct and desire to lead a useful and reasonably long life, close to those we love, and to have some warning of approaching death, but not too long to suffer. However, we cannot plan for everything in life. We cannot control every aspect of it, so we must have confidence that, close to death, all the necessary support will be available. The quick fix should not be seen as the solution.

In many respects, advances in medicine have meant that many more people are living longer. Some become disabled and make demands on family and community for the care that is required, but not all people who suffer from terminal illness are old.

While nursing in a hospital I experienced my fair share of caring for the dying. Although that was now many years ago, I still vividly remember those people and those experiences with death. In more recent years, my experiences were closer to diagnosis of disease, some of which resulted in terminal illness. I have been there when people in the prime of their lives have been diagnosed with diseases such as breast cancer and leukemia. I have been there when their progress and treatment has been monitored.

These experiences have given me a good and, I confess, painful insight into those who suffer. It seemed that it was easier to manage the physical pain than the mental pain of depression and anguish. But I have seen people grow with acceptance and the real desire to make the most of the time available to them. I have known the dying to fight for extra time just to remember some good experiences of their life or to spend time with family and loved ones.

As has been observed by medical practitioners in the field of pain management, calls by a patient for an end to life in times of extreme suffering have often been temporary and due to unfair pressures placed upon them, or have simply been a cry for help and attention. One doctor has written to me saying:

My experience is that patients will occasionally say, "I want to die, I've had enough." This is often a cry for help from a depressed person. Once good palliative care has been provided they very frequently change their mind.
A palliative care worker has also commented:
With the proper palliative care, there's the capacity to transcend the most extraordinary physical suffering: and even in the terminal phase of life, there can be enormous growth and understanding.

Euthanasia may be an attractive option for those with proper family support who have organised their affairs and put their emotional matters in order, but it is for the disadvantaged, the disabled and the vulnerable that the provision of euthanasia introduces a dangerous uncertainty when they are least able to cope.

Overseas experiences have already shown that the provision of euthanasia to consenting patients has been impossible to police. There have been five extensive inquiries into the implications of legalising euthanasia: the Law Reform Commission in Canada in 1982; the Parliament of Victoria in 1987; the House of Lords in 1994; the New York State Task Force in 1994; and the Senate of Canada only last year. Those inquiries all found it impossible to make the law safe and make vulnerable people free from the risk of abuse. I do not believe the Northern Territory's euthanasia bill addresses those concerns.

In the future, with increasing health costs and an ageing population, and in the knowledge that individuals access health services the most in the first and last stages of life, we must never have in place legislation which signals that an empty bed is a better outcome than appropriate care for the terminally ill.

One American commentator has said, `The patient often seems to have been most worried about the disease's impact on others. It is possible that a certain type of woman—depressive, self-effacing, near the end of a life largely spent serving others—is particularly vulnerable to the "rational-heroic" solution of euthanasia.'

I also have concerns for non‐English speaking patients. There is already a shortage of translators working in the health system. Also, the Northern Territory's significant Aboriginal communities have many concerns about the provision of euthanasia services in the territory.

The long-term implications of legalising execution through the agency of the healing profession does more than undermine the doctor-patient relationship. It fundamentally changes the moral underpinning of the care giving services in our society. These are fundamental and national concerns and it is only right and proper that they are decided by the national parliament.
The majority of doctors do not want this type of publicly sanctioned power of executioner, as a constituent of mine, Dr Pollnitz, has written to me on this issue. He wrote:

Sadly, some of my colleagues cannot be trusted with the right to kill. There are doctors whose own peculiar emotional needs are met by the blend of power and intimacy in a death-dealing relationship. . . It can be argued that those doctors who are most interested in performing euthanasia are those whose own emotional needs in the matter should disqualify them.

I am proud to say that South Australia was the first Australian state to enact advanced directive legislation in the form of a Natural Death Act in 1983 and later the Consent to Medical Treatment and Palliative Care Act in 1995. It was the first time in the world an act of parliament gave legal protection to doctors who administer treatment to relieve pain, even if death was hastened as a result. I believe this type of legislation is a sensible approach.
The Northern Territory's act does not empower patients with real choice. It emphasises the physical act of terminal illness but ignores the emotional and mental aspects of the closing stages of life.
I would like to conclude by quoting an editorial in last Wednesday's Sydney Morning Herald:

The idea that it is possible, in a law permitting assisted suicide, to make it safe by stipulating conditions which prevent abuses is dangerously false. The existence of any law which condones, not forbids, means that there will be scope for clever, muddled or sinister manipulation. That means deaths which should not occur. That is why the Federal Parliament should override the Northern Territory law.
I commend this bill to the parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is when an issue such as euthanasia is thrust upon us that our grave responsibilities as federal members are brought home. As with most people, I have had to conduct a thorough self-examination while deliberating on how I would vote on this bill. I will be voting in support of the member for Menzies' (Mr Andrews) private member's bill.

SPEECH.PARA: When Mr Andrews' bill was first introduced to the House and the issue of a conscience vote was raised, I was asked by one of my constituents whether it would receive my support. At the time I told him I disagreed totally with active euthanasia. He then pointed to the public opinion polls which have repeatedly found a very high percentage of Australians in favour of legal euthanasia, especially of the kind introduced in the Northern Territory. The answer I gave him, and which I will repeat for the benefit of this chamber, is that when it comes to popularity polls and the like, politicians, perhaps more so than anybody else, have a right to remain sceptical. On the question of those polls in particular I think the oft used line of `Lies, damned lies and statistics' has never been more appropriate.

In the letters I have received in my office, from the people I talk to in the street, at local events or even in local clubs, I have found that there is a widespread misunderstanding of what is meant by the term `euthanasia.' For example, there is a failure among many people to whom I talk to appreciate the subtleties that exist between passive voluntary euthanasia and active voluntary euthanasia, a failure which I expect is shared by many people throughout the rest of this country. It is this misunderstanding which I believe is driving much of the support for euthanasia in those polls. When this disappears I think much of that support will disappear with it.

Informed decision making has been made even harder thanks to the media's soft focus portrayal of suffering people pleading to be allowed to die under the Northern Territory's new laws. It is entirely understandable that Australians, confronted with images of the sick and the dying on their television sets and in their newspapers, sympathise with their plight and let their hearts and minds go out to them. As such I am surprised that the percentage of people in favour of euthanasia in the polls is not a lot higher.

At the same time, I think there has been a tendency on the media's part to portray those opposed to euthanasia as cold‐hearted and unemotional religious robots. Let me state for the record that religion has nothing to do with the reasons why I object to active voluntary euthanasia. To my mind, we are yet to see a balanced account given on the level of palliative care on offer in this country. We are yet to hear the voices of the great majority of doctors who find the notion of assisting in active euthanasia utterly repugnant and beyond the boundaries of medicine as it should be practised.

What we have not seen are the case histories from the Netherlands and the truly frightening picture which is starting to reveal itself in that country. I have had people say, `But doctors should be able to turn off a life support system when they are not achieving anything.' I agree with them. People have also said, `If a patient's treatment is not proving beneficial, and it is just prolonging the agony before death, the patient should have the right to insist on the treatment being stopped and be allowed to die with dignity.' Again, I agree with that. These people are under the misunderstanding that to do these things is to commit euthanasia, that it is these practices which the bill of the member for Menzies hopes to put to an end.

Turning off life support systems and withholding fruitless medical treatment is not euthanasia; it is common medical practice. This is an example of medicine as it is carried out in Australian hospitals day in and day out. Under Australian common law a competent adult patient can refuse to consent to the initiation or the continuance of medical treatment. The doctor must respect any such voluntary or sufficiently informed refusal of medical treatment.

It is when I give these people a clear and hopefully unbiased account of the active voluntary euthanasia to which I am opposed—that is, the lawful termination of one person's life by another in the case of incurable illness—that the indignation or misunderstanding written across the faces of those people I am talking to begins to disappear. The scales fall from their eyes.

But the polls are a problematic diversion from the main argument. There are of course the questions of human decency, of what value we wish to place on human life in our society, that lead me to oppose active voluntary euthanasia. It is my belief that to sanction the legal termination, the lawful killing, of one person by another—however sick and distressed the patient may be or however well‐meaning or medically qualified the person carrying out the termination is—is to cheapen human life beyond all acceptable levels. How can we, as a society, refuse to permit the death penalty for our most heinous criminals and yet allow death to be meted out to those whom we cherish the most?

How could we hold our heads up living in a society where we profess to consider life as the most treasured of gifts, where to intentionally take a life is the most serious crime imaginable, while at the same time cultivating a culture of easy death? I agree with the House of Lords Select Committee on Medical Ethics which found in its report published in 1993 that:

BREAK.PARA: . . . dying is not only a personal or individual affair. The death of a person affects the lives of others, often in ways and to an extent which cannot be foreseen. We believe that the issue of euthanasia is one in which the interests of the individual cannot be separated from the society or the interest of society as a whole.

To allow active voluntary euthanasia into our midst is to allow a destabilisation of one of the basic tenets which underpins our society. We cannot entertain the gross hypocrisy of saying, `Life in our society is sacred, but . . . '. The minute we start qualifying our innate belief in the sanctity of life, no matter how noble or benign active voluntary euthanasia may appear, we are setting a precedent, a precedent from which we cannot comprehend the ramifications.

Other members may have recently received a letter from a Miss Cecily Miner, a young woman who suffers from the extremely rare and debilitating auto‐immune disorder, Behcet's disease. Miss Miner's letter is one of the most harrowing, most distressing testimonials of personal illness I have ever read. It is also the most inspiring and I suggest that all members, who have not at this time read that letter, take the opportunity and read the words of such an exceptionally brave woman. Miss Miner is a woman who has endured a lot of pain and suffering, at levels which most people would find very difficult to comprehend, and yet euthanasia, for her, remains an anathema. In part of her letter she says:

I believe euthanasia is dangerous and fundamentally misguided as a solution to great physical suffering . . . I believe the debate over euthanasia deflects attention away from the real issues—how to manage a large proportion of the community who need ongoing medical support and how to advance the search for more effective and less harmful pain relief.
That is one of the main issues of this whole debate. Why are we considering taking the easy option? Why not make more of an effort into looking at better medicines and improving palliative care?

The human race, for all its faults, has always strived to improve things, to better its lot. Are we going to be the first to throw up our hands, take the easy option, and say, `Oh no, this is all too hard, it is too difficult! Give us euthanasia and let us forget all about it'? Is that what we want to say?
I have already mentioned the situation in the Netherlands. Let me quote from an article in the New Scientist magazine of 20 June 1992. It stated:

At least a third of the 5,000 or so Dutch patients who each year receive lethal doses of drugs from their doctors do not give their unequivocal consent. About 400 of these patients never even raise the issue of euthanasia with their doctors. Moreover, of those who willingly opt for euthanasia, only about 5 per cent do so solely because of unbearable pain. A much higher proportion, about a third, do so partly for fear of becoming dependent on others.
This shocking excerpt speaks for itself. The last sentence is especially worth noting, considering the paucity of beds for palliative care in the Northern Territory.

The Netherlands and Australia are different countries, but they are not on different planets. I do not think it is too long a bow to draw to assert that what we have seen happening over there is what we will see occurring here if we allow the Northern Territory's legislation to stand.

There are those who point to the alarming picture in the Netherlands as a reason why we need to legislate for active voluntary euthanasia and bring it under the careful scrutiny of authorities. I cannot see legislation, however strict, stopping physicians, inured to death, bending the rules when they see fit, cutting corners when it seems to them to make sense.

Doctors, of course, are no more innately dismissive of the law than anybody else in society. But that is the point. There are individuals in all walks of life, in all professions, who step outside the law when it suits them or when, in their eyes, they perceive the law to be an ass—physicians included. I can see doctors in the Northern Territory turning a blind eye to elements of the euthanasia law as though they were no more than speed signs on a highway.

I would like to turn to the reservations expressed by those senators representing both of the major territories in this parliament that this debate should not be treated as a debate on the rights and wrongs of euthanasia but, rather, as a debate on the effect on the role and responsibilities of the legislative assemblies of the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory. The Australian territories are just that—territories. Until they achieve statehood, the constitutional mores that govern the relationship between the territories and the Commonwealth must remain supreme.

If I had more time, I would refer to the legal qualifications of Justice Lockhart in the Federal Court case, Attorney‐General (Northern Territory) v. Hand, in 1989. The Commonwealth, I believe, is not suddenly casting itself as some sort of meddlesome aunt, as the senators have suggested. It is merely performing the role set out for it which is protected by our constitution.

There are so many things I would like to have said in the main chamber with the time allocated there, rather than this 10 minutes. However, I believe that we must never have in our society in Australia a law which means that we can legally take another's life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks, Noel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have requested to take part in the debate on the Euthanasia Laws Bill because I believe the matter of so‐called mercy killing or euthanasia to be one of the most significant issues of modern times. This is reflected in the large volume of mail and other contacts I have received on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: This debate far surpasses in importance any of the debates which have taken place in this parliament during the time that I have been a federal member. What we are debating here today is the intentional killing of another person by act or omission and that that act should be made permissible through the enactment of legislation.

Throughout my parliamentary career, spanning 16 years, I have been a supporter of states rights, but what the Northern Territory government proposes is a legal structure for killing. Whether the Northern Territory was a state or a territory or any other form of jurisdiction, I could not agree to a move which would detrimentally affect the people of Australia, particularly the weak and the vulnerable.

I commend the member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) for his courage in bringing this private member's bill, known as the Northern Territory Self‐Government Amendment Bill 1996, before the federal parliament. At the outset, may I say that, from the time I can remember, I have opposed euthanasia on religious grounds. As I understand it, euthanasia is forbidden in the Jewish, Christian and Muslim faiths.

Whilst I have heard the argument by some pro‐euthanasia advocates that the religious views of some should not be thrust upon others, I believe that, as an Australian, I should be permitted to take part in this debate and put another point of view that may not be in keeping with the secular humanist approach of the pro‐euthanasia lobby.

Recently a group of Aboriginal elders from the Yolnu people of Arnhem Land visited the parliament to protest the introduction of euthanasia into the Northern Territory parliamentary law, saying that it was totally against their law or the Madayin. The Madayin law is the complete system of law that the Yolnu people believe provides them with the right and civilised way to live, and it encompasses the moral, social and religious laws of the Yolnu people. According to their beliefs, the Madayin comes from the beginning of time. Here is another group of Australians whom I was afforded the privilege of consulting, who are not of the `Book', but who are opposed to euthanasia because they are aware of its dangers.

Having said that, however, I have known for many years that if a case was to be made against so‐called mercy killing, it had to be based on a logical and ethical argument rather than on a religious stance. This is not because there is hostility to religion in this country, but rather because there is a great apathy. I knew that eventually no member of the parliament could escape this debate, which strikes at the very heart of our civilisation, and I have made the study of euthanasia one of my priorities.

I have placed great importance on the issue because I believe that what we are debating will, in the future, have a profound influence on who is considered worthy or unworthy to live, and the attitude Western civilisation will take toward the weak and the vulnerable. If the proponents of euthanasia are allowed to have their way, we will enter an age of great social uncertainty, a time when no‐one will be certain of their future, particularly if they become ill or infirm. It will inevitably determine the future social conscience and attitude towards the unwell, the elderly and the disabled.

It has been said many times before that the German doctors in the early 1930s who worked to have euthanasia introduced, possibly for what they perceived to be the right reasons, were the precursors of the Holocaust. Although it started with disabled children in Germany, today in Australia it has commenced with the seriously ill and tomorrow it will be the elderly and children who are perceived by some as having no future potential to contribute to society.

Then it would move to other groups, as it has done in other civilisations throughout history. Under the Third Reich, the euthanasia program started, as it has in the Northern Territory, with all the best intentions. It was broadened until it included the so‐called `superfluous people', the unfit, the unproductive, the useless eaters, the misfits and the undesirables. The overall picture is best understood as the identification and the elimination of the weak. Ironically, in Germany the Jews were initially excluded from the program because they were considered unworthy of its so‐called benefits. Eventually, however, they were rounded up and treated as members of a diseased race that acted as a parasite on the German people.

The concepts of a `life not worth living' and `death with dignity' propelled the genocide program to the national socialists in Germany. Euthanasia proponents decried parallels between the euthanasia movement and what the Nazis did. In no way would I suggest that the proponents of euthanasia in Australia are inclined that way. Nevertheless, humanity's interest in aborting a recurrence of anything resembling the national socialist genocide program decrees that we should compare the thought and practices taking place in our country with those that took place in Germany in the first half of this century.

I am sure when the movement towards euthanasia was first taken in Germany, before it was hijacked by the national socialists, it would have been with the best of intentions. However, as in Germany, here in Australia the movement toward active, involuntary euthanasia is being precipitated by the rejection of natural law, jurisprudence and the acceptance of positivistic utilitarianism and secularism.

According to Anne Potter in her article, `Will the "right to die" become a "licence to kill"?' the euthanasia push under the Third Reich germinated from a short but influential book published in 1920. The book, entitled Release of the destruction of life devoid of value, was written by the jurist Karl Binding and the psychiatrist Alfred Hoche. In their publication, Hoche and Binding's reasoning resembles that of euthanasia proponents today. The book starts with a focus on voluntary euthanasia for suffering, terminally ill patients, but this discussion becomes a springboard proposal that euthanasia be extended to a larger circle of people. The greatest fear to me today is that throughout their book, written 76 years ago, Hoche and Binding trumpet the economic argument of euthanasia.

As has been discussed in the Australian parliament recently, the pressure on funding for Medicare, which is now blowing out and compounding, will put extraordinary pressure on the budget, as will Australia's rapidly aging population. The same thing is occurring in the United States where the euthanasia debate is raging.

Hoche and Binding point out how much manpower, patience and capital investment is invested to keep life, which they term as not worth living, alive until finally, often awfully late, nature triumphs in death. They denounce the treatment of the mentally sick, whom they term `creatures of no value at all', and call upon legislation to abandon this commitment to the sacredness of life.

Hoche and Binding were not Hitler's advisers. Nevertheless, they significantly influenced the current thought of their time. Under the Third Reich, the concept of life not worthy of life slowly became popularised. Cost containment concerns like those presently being raised in Australia fed the euthanasia frenzy in Germany.

In 1941 the film I accuse, based on the novel Mission and Conscience, depicted a physician giving a lethal injection to his incurably ill wife in response to her desperate plea to be relieved of her suffering. In polls conducted to ascertain the impact of the film, many Germans accepted the film's argument of voluntary euthanasia in principle. There is a chilling similarity between that poll and the poll recently taken in Australia which claimed that 70 to 80 per cent of the population was in favour of voluntary euthanasia.

As with Australia's first death from euthanasia, in Germany the first death came by request. A father asked that his child who was retarded, blind, and missing a leg and part of one arm, should be euthanased. Hitler's physician Dr Brandt, after inquiry at Hitler's direction, informed the child's physician that the child could be euthanased. Subsequently, a program was prepared for killing children deemed to have no prospect of a meaningful life. The rest is now history. And the sad fact is that the doctors involved were not trained as medical monsters, but they perceived that what they were doing was furthering the good of society.
Early this week I got a letter from an Australian of Dutch heritage. It says:
Dear Noel

As a young boy in Holland during the war I recall the story where my father told me that one night a German soldier—we were occupied—came crying into our market garden with a letter from a senior officer in which he was advised that his mother was put to sleep because she was mentally unstable. The soldier told my father that his mother was old but not mentally ill, but very concerned about him, her only son, in another country in the army.

Need I say more. Following the Nuremberg trials the proponents of euthanasia were reasonably quiet until, in 1981, a court in Rotterdam laid down the basic criteria for the practice of euthanasia. It explicitly decreed that the patient must be in extreme pain, must have considered the alternatives, and must freely consent to be killed; further decision cannot be taken by one doctor alone, must be carefully reasoned through and carried out by a licensed physician. Numerous alleged safeguards were built into the Dutch practice—as the proponents of the Northern Territory euthanasia laws tell us are in the Northern Territory legislation.

What has been the result in the Netherlands? According to the Dutch government's own figures, in 1990 nearly one‐third of the 3,300 official cases of euthanasia were carried out without the patient's consent. On top of that, there were 8,100 cases in which doctors gave patients drugs with the express intention of hastening their demise, but which were not officially recorded as euthanasia because the doctors also intended to relieve pain. Of those 8,100 cases, 27 per cent were capable of giving their consent, but 60 per cent of that number were never asked. And so the numbers go on. All of this in a country with judge‐made laws, tacitly approved by parliament and the executive, which on paper are every bit as strict as the Northern Territory legislation.

So what becomes of criticism of the slippery slope argument? Why should we believe the Northern Territory experience will be any different? I know this matter is one of great complexity, and I must acknowledge I am speaking as a reasonably healthy individual. But who knows what will happen tomorrow? One thing I am certain of is that one day, like everyone, I must face death. But I am unsure what pain I must suffer before that occurs. My wish for that time is that I am in the company of loved ones, that I have access to palliative care, and that those who tend me have a compassion for their fellow human.

In conclusion, I would like to identify with the woman whom the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) previously mentioned who wrote to me detailing the terrible suffering she has experienced over the years and the fact that when she developed her illness she prayed to die. At the end of her letter she says:

I don't want to live in a society where the weakest, most cowardly and most lazy option is enshrined in legislation. I want to live in an enlightened society where the sick are valued and where the prevention and relief of pain are highly prized and addressed as highest priorities.
As for euthanasia, I am dead against it.
Yours sincerely—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that parliament should be debating the Euthanasia Laws Bill, regardless of what chamber it might be in. Questions such as euthanasia and other moral issues are the responsibility of the individual. It is arrogant in the extreme that we, as members of parliament, should put our morality on others. Because we have a particular religious belief or feel strongly on a moral issue, what right have we to insist that others concur with our view? Perhaps, as some have suggested, a referendum on the issue should be conducted.

SPEECH.PARA: If that is not reason enough to oppose this legislation, I have always fundamentally believed in the rights of the states and I thought that was the philosophy of the Liberal Party. I have heard debate after debate on states rights, yet here we are overriding legislation properly enacted by the Northern Territory parliament. This states rights argument is not, as one colleague claimed, the weakest argument against the bill.

Although some argue that this legislation would only apply to the territories, such as the ACT and the NT, make no mistake—if this parliament uses its power to override Northern Territory legislation we are opening a Pandora's box: every time a federal MP objects to some state law, we will be here debating the issue. If we override this legislation, within six months we will be having a divisive debate about abortion. This will be followed up by a debate on capital punishment, a debate on homosexuality or a debate on the environment.

BREAK.PARA: There are many laws passed by individual states that I strongly object to, but I have never objected to any state or territory's right to pass laws that they see as affecting their own citizens, regardless of how strongly I may personally feel about the issue. I strongly respect the views of those who, on religious, moral or social grounds, object to euthanasia. It is my hope that they would respect my view, as I support voluntary euthanasia. This is a point that is so often overlooked in this debate: we are talking about voluntary euthanasia.

Like all members, I have received a lot of well‐argued documentation for both sides of this debate, but I do feel it unfortunate that many of those arguing to outlaw euthanasia have used cheap and emotive arguments about murder. What we are talking about here is voluntary euthanasia. The arguments have been canvassed about palliative care or the right to die with dignity, and I will not repeat them here. Suffice it to say that I once watched a friend of mine die a slow and agonising death. He knew he had a terminal illness and approached several of his friends on many occasions, asking them to assist him to die.

Obviously, we discussed this. What we all did, instead of assisting him, was to make sure that any methods enabling him to take his life were kept locked away, and we watched him closely. In the end this friend, when close to death, could stand it no longer and threw himself off a cliff. I suggest that we were wrong in not assisting him in ending his life. If there had been legislation, such as that in the Northern Territory today, he would have been able to die with dignity. Not only could he have died with dignity but his friends would have been relieved of the guilt feeling they now have of not having been able to assist him.

There is nothing beautiful in watching a person dying in agony, screaming in pain and delirious with the impact of medication—as happened with my own sister. It is not as if, in society, a form of euthanasia is not conducted, with doctors now making that decision. The decision should be taken from the doctors and from others, and placed where it really belongs: with the individual. There are, of course, a number of scare campaigns running. We have all had the emotive letters accusing those of us who support euthanasia of legalising murder. The case must be very weak if those supporting the Andrews bill have to rely on such emotive arguments.

I cannot understand how anyone who believes in the basic freedom of the individual could deny an individual the right to voluntary euthanasia if they so choose. It is not as if a person could suddenly have a bad day and decide to end their life. They have to be suffering a terminal illness, and there has to be a second opinion: there are very many safeguards. I have heard the argument saying that this is the start of the slippery slide. But the safeguards are in place, and all the nonsense that people talk—about family pressure and the elderly being made to feel a burden—is exactly that: nonsense.

For those who do not support voluntary euthanasia, that is their right; and no‐one would force voluntary or involuntary euthanasia on them. But why should people who do not agree with euthanasia force their views on people who do agree with it? It is a fundamental human right for people to die with dignity, and I cannot understand why people can oppose it. If I had a life‐threatening illness, I would choose voluntary euthanasia. That is my right, and I do not see why that right should be denied me. For those who oppose voluntary euthanasia, that is also their right. It is a right I respect, but I cannot accept that that right enables them to put their own views, morality, and beliefs concerning life and death onto others. They should not deny anyone this basic human choice.

I have heard members say that they could not support the state taking of life. Like the honourable member for Watson (Mr McLeay), I oppose capital punishment. I have always opposed capital punishment. I am a pacifist, but this is not about the state taking a life. It is about an individual choice. It is not state sanctioned killing, but an individual choice. At the conclusion of his speech, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) said, `I hope that we have the courage to deal with such an issue of profound importance to this nation and to the people of Australia.' As I said before, I believe sincerely that this parliament has no right to be debating this issue of personal morality.

Most speakers in this debate have quoted from letters to support their case, and there is nothing wrong with that. Since everyone has been quoting from letters, let me quote from a letter. It is from Bob Dent, the first person to have voluntary euthanasia in Australia. He wrote:

I read with increasing horror newspapers stories of Kevin Andrews' attempt to overturn the most compassionate piece of legislation in the world. The Church and State must remain separate. What right has anyone because of their religious faith to demand that I behave according to their rules until some omniscient doctor decides that I must have had enough and goes ahead and increases my morphine until I die?

As I have tried to explain, I have no argument with people who oppose euthanasia. I respect their point of view. But why, because of their opposition, should they put their view on me or on anyone else? As the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Hicks) so rightly says, it is an issue that we all have to face. When my time comes I will take the decision and, regardless of what legislation might be in place, I will exercise my right to exit this life with as much dignity as I can. I hope that, if I have a terminal illness, I have the option of euthanasia. I totally support the view of Bob Dent. What he said I passionately believe, and I will quote him:
If you disagree with voluntary euthanasia, then don't use it, but don't deny me the right to use it if and when I want to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been in the parliament for 16 years, and there has never before been an occasion when I have had the opportunity to participate in a debate on a question which is as intensely moral and personal as this question is. Let me at this stage indicate my objection to the fact that the debate is being conducted in the Main Committee. This is not because I have any disrespect for this chamber—I was chairman of the Standing Committee on Procedure when we reported on it, and it had been operating very effectively—but the Main Committee was not established for this purpose. Debate on questions as intensely moral and personal as this question should be conducted in the main chamber, and members should have the opportunity to speak about the question more fully.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to emphasise, as well, that I am not very concerned about the possibility that the federal government might overrule territory or state legislation. If it is considered to be appropriate within the constitutional rights of the federal government, then I am quite comfortable about that, particularly if it involves extending the rights of individuals or if it involves protecting the Australian community in any number of ways. This question is one that I have to resolve on the basis, essentially, of how I relate to it personally.

In that context, let me make this point: I have already completed, in a legal form, a power of attorney with the appointment of a patient advocate with an advance directive to ensure that, in the event of my suffering a number of seriously debilitating and irreversible circumstances, people that I love will have the opportunity to make decisions which I may not be able to make for myself. I am indebted to the Voluntary Euthanasia Society for the basic draft of that document. In connection with that, in the event of certain identified debilitating circumstances afflicting me, I have directed:
(1) that I am not to be subjected to any medical intervention or treatment aimed at prolonging or sustaining my life;

(2) that any distressing symptoms (including any caused by lack of food or fluid) are to be fully controlled by appropriate analgesic or other treatment, even though that treatment may shorten my life.

I have modified the statement—the draft of which, as I say, I am indebted to the Voluntary Euthanasia Society for providing—in the following way, because it was not, for my purposes, strong enough. I have added this:
IN THE PARTICULAR CIRCUMSTANCES IN WHICH
(1) I am afflicted by one or more of the conditions mentioned in the schedule—
and they are identified—
and

(2) despite not being subjected to any intervention or treatment aimed at prolonging my life my life is being unreasonably prolonged by natural causes to the point where I lose the physical and/or mental capacity to act rationally, independently and with an acceptable level of human dignity, then, I direct and authorise that positive intervention be provided to either assist me to terminate my life or to terminate it for me if I am unable to do so.

I have three beautiful grandchildren. I have attempted to live and to lead a moral and dignified life. Everyone has to die. But in the period immediately before my death I do not want to suffer, consciously or unconsciously, my three beautiful grandchildren seeing their grandfather lose his personal dignity by growing senility, degeneration, physical and mental decay. I find that prospect absolutely horrifying. So to those people who would seek to restrict my right to determine the timing and nature of my leaving this life I simply say, `Do not do so.' I ask them not to do so.

This question is about voluntary euthanasia. It was referred to this Main Committee and at this time we have here eight members, in addition to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, of a 148‐member House of Representatives. We have 10 minutes each to consider the most moral and personal question that I have ever been involved in considering in this parliament in 16 years. I supported the proposition that it should have been referred in the first place to a special committee, which was the motion moved by the member for Longman (Mr Brough). It should have been. It would have given an opportunity for our peers, by way of a select committee, to consider some of the doubts that are involved.

I would challenge some of my colleagues to identify clearly the difference between voluntary, involuntary and non-voluntary euthanasia, between active and passive euthanasia, and to distinguish them, in turn, from assisted suicide. They need to be able to do that in order to cast a sensible vote in connection with this question. I would challenge all my colleagues on both sides of the chamber who decided that that special select committee would not be established to resolve the very compelling legal question where competent legal opinion says this legislation will not impact adversely on other elements of Northern Territory legislation and equally competent legal opinion says it will. Until we resolve questions of that kind I have very great doubt about whether any of us can cast a sensible and a rational vote.

I also make this point, which is a matter of enormous moral concern to me: if euthanasia remains a criminal act, there must be criminal sanctions. We cannot allow good, compassionate, moral people who assist others to die—including an estimated 7,000 doctors practising in Australia at the present time—to take the risk of being criminals and incarcerated. Early last year, seven doctors in Victoria went on the public record to say they had assisted their patients to die. That is a criminal act. They could have been incarcerated for 14 years. But in their courage and their morality they made that public statement.

As legislators, we depend on the compassion of the law enforcement authorities and on the compassion and morality of the courts not to convict those people. That is an act of personal and political cowardice. We wash our hands. We say, `The courts are compassionate. They will not convict moral, honest, courageous people.' And we leave the criminal law in place. Let me repeat: that is an act of personal and political cowardice. As legislators, we have a responsibility to give the lead to the courts and the law enforcement authorities, and we choose not to do so.

Any number of examples have been given in connection with these particular questions. There have been letters quoted from; there have been particular cases referred to. In the unfortunately limited time available, let me refer to some of them. I refer to Esme Rushton from the Dandenongs. Early last year she said that she hoped that at the end of the line for her, when the pain gets too much, she can die in her leafy mountain home, not in a geriatric ward. She said, `I will take a pill or a few pills and just go to bed and not wake up.' She said, `Why should you suffer to die when you are going to die anyway? I mean the thought of becoming a vegetable and have people having to look after me is terrifying.'

I share Esme Rushton's concern. I have seen the most debilitated, senile people in the worst wards of the nursing homes and they do not deserve that. I do not deserve that. My children and my grandchildren and those people I love do not deserve that. So I say to people, `If you do not want to have available to you voluntary euthanasia, please don't deny that right to me!'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gambaro, Teresa, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Eight years ago, the Greer family moved in next door. Roger had been a successful director of a large advertising agency until a brain tumour struck. The tumour was treated and he was on the road to recovery, until further brain tumours were discovered. The reason I tell this story is because it changed the way that I look at the whole dying process. I saw the wonderful palliative care provided to Roger. His family and friends would visit and sit with him; his wife, Barbara, cared for and loved him in the most exquisite way. Life was precious and every moment of it was to be savoured.

SPEECH.PARA: I met some wonderful people who cared for Roger. One was a palliative care sister named Margaret Gully. Margaret was the closest that one could come to a living angel. Roger joked about his brain tumour early in the piece and said that he needed it like a hole in the head. His sense of humour stayed with him until the very end. The process of dying was an intimate and caring experience that family and friends participated in and shared. This brilliant man passed away and I was deeply touched by his family and the great care and love that was provided to him.

The word `euthanasia' comes from the Greek `eu' and `thanatos', which means an easy death. The greatest fear that we mortals have is the fear of dying. Many of us, God bless, will die peacefully and tranquilly in our sleep. For others this will not be the case. As far back as ancient times, man has been terrified of his own mortality. We are the only creatures who bury our dead; the rest of the animal kingdom does not. The sight of a dead human body in the decaying process in ancient times was a reminder of our fragility and the darkness of death.

Kevin Andrews' Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996 seeks to overturn the Northern Territory euthanasia bill passed by the Legislative Assembly in May 1996. The Northern Territory bill is based on the simple principle: if there are terminally ill patients who wish to end their suffering by accelerating inevitable death, and there are sympathetic doctors who are willing to help them to die with dignity, the law should not forbid it.

The Northern Territory bill proposes and states that a person asking for assistance must be an adult; be terminally ill and diagnosed to die within 12 months; be mentally competent; make the request in writing; be advised about the nature of the illness and the palliative care and medical treatment available; be experiencing severe pain or suffering distress with no medical treatment reasonably available to offer relief; and be examined by a second medical practitioner to confirm the circumstances and fulfil all the statutory requirements set down by the bill.

Only after all the above have been fulfilled will a doctor be able to prescribe a lethal substance to be self-administered. The bill prohibits anyone appointing a relative or an agent to make a life‐shortening decision on their behalf. The letter of the law will continue to apply to anyone who takes the life of another or who attempts to take life in all other circumstances. The laws in relation to homicide apply now and continue to apply.

There are many arguments that have been put forward in support of euthanasia and against the Andrews bill, such as those advocated by Dr Roger Hunt, Dr Robert Marr and Professor Peter Baume. They say that the Northern Territory bill is a long overdue reform and that eight out of 10 Australians want voluntary euthanasia decriminalised. They believe that the Andrews bill will keep the practice of euthanasia unregulated, without safeguards and surveillance; it will undermine the patient's autonomy and leave end of life decisions in the hands of the doctors; it will invalidate the Northern Territory's Natural Death Act of 1988, which allows dying patients to refuse life‐sustaining treatment.

They say that it will impact upon and render ineffective crucial elements of the criminal code in the Northern Territory; it casts doubts on the legality of life‐shortening palliative care; it will increase fear of prosecutions and uncertainty in the medical profession in the care of dying patients; and it will deny dying patients the right to choose how much suffering they have to endure.

The first point I wish to make is that, although research states that 80 per cent of people are supportive of euthanasia and it is popular, it does not necessarily make it right. Death is inevitable, and it is the process of death and dying that frightens us the most. The May 1996 position statement of the Australian Medical Association's federal council included some of the following points: The AMA believes that doctors should not be involved in interventions that have, as the primary goal, the ending of a person's life; the AMA endorses the right of patients to refuse treatment and the right of severely and terminally ill patients to have relief of pain and suffering, even when such therapy may shorten a patient's life.

For society to invest in any group the power to administer death is to make life negotiable—and it is not. To believe that doctors acting individually or in concert would act honestly is idealistic in the extreme. It defies history. To believe that they will never make a mistake is to indulge in fantasy.

The previous Governor‐General of Australia, Mr Bill Hayden, referred to the frail and elderly as `unproductive burdens' and said that succeeding generations deserve to be disencumbered of some of these burdens. What does that mean to a lonely old person already suffering low self‐esteem and a sense of being a burden? These elderly people will feel that euthanasia is not a choice but an expectation of them to do the right thing.

BREAK.PARA: The Canadian Supreme Court judgment in 1993 said that the responsibility of government to protect the vulnerable people from abuse outweighs any individual right to assisted suicide. The conclusion of the House of Lords in 1994 was:

It would be impossible to ensure that every act of euthanasia was truly voluntary. We are concerned that vulnerable people, the elderly, lonely, sick or distressed would feel pressure, whether real or imagined, to request early death.

Palliative care in the United Kingdom has been developed to a very high standard. With appropriate management, pain, distress and suffering in all terminal illness can be totally relieved in all but a minority of cases.

Many people also stress the importance of dealing with the psychological, social and spiritual distress suffered by many dying individuals. The improvement of palliative care in Australia is really what is needed—not euthanasia. According to Dr Colleen McCullough in a recent report, Putting People Down, which she presented to the New South Wales parliament in March 1996:
The right to life, whatever its quality, is universal and sacred among humankind. Those who genuinely want to die will find a way to suicide without assistance.

She believes that those who ask others to kill them do not genuinely want to die. Throughout the ages, to summon a physician indicated a will to live. To ask a physician to administer death is anathema.

The euthanasia issue is one that is close to the moral and social conscience of many. I have had many letters, phone calls and personal representations from constituents. Although my personal beliefs are important, I have to weigh up the conscience and feeling of those in the Petrie electorate to ensure that I vote, not just for myself but for the majority of the people I represent. The majority of those who have contacted my office are in favour of the Andrews bill.

I would like to express some of the comments of people from my electorate. Their comments both for and against euthanasia are moving and each one has a story behind it. Those advocates for the Andrews bill say:

It is not through lack of compassion that the rest of the world has rejected euthanasia. Rather it is because of the realistic knowledge that a law permitting the use of lethal injections in hospitals could never be safe.
It is true that palliative care is a much better option for those desperately ill patients. Encouraging them to take their own lives is a failure of the love and care we should have for each other.
To hope that all doctors will exercise so‐called euthanasia rights with total compassion is being idealistic in the extreme. Herein lies the danger to the weak—the aged—the mentally ill.
I believe strongly in the value and dignity of human life and feel that allowing euthanasia is not recognising that value.
Other comments presented include:
The Northern Territory's laws on euthanasia. . . well thought out and should never be tampered with by our federal government.
Another person wrote to me:
. . . every individual should have free choice to have their life terminated in the appropriate circumstances and under the umbrella of a well‐defined law.
Another constituent writes:
I support the Northern Territory in the acceptance of people deciding for themselves on how they wish to die.
And, finally, a nurse who wrote:
I am a nurse who is dealing with the terminally ill. . . I would like to have that choice.

However, my feelings on this are that life is precious and that no act of parliament should decide who lives and who dies. We as a society need to take greater responsibility and control of our sick and our elderly. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make it clear at the outset that I oppose the Andrews bill. Even if I did not believe in euthanasia I would still be opposing it because it is clearly an affront to the rights of the people of the Northern Territory. I would not like it to be thought that I condone statehood for the Northern Territory. At the first opportunity I will vote for its abolition. But while the situation is as it is, it is clearly a decision for the people of the Northern Territory to make and through their elected representatives they have made it.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the measure of any civilisation is how it treats its young and its old and on that score I think our civilisation has many things to answer for. The process of dying can be, as some members have said, a lovely experience, for others it is not so. I have watched my brother die over the last few years. He was buried a few weeks ago; a man who was a superb athlete stricken with a disease which gradually crippled him. He died a quadriplegic with his brain entirely intact. I know there were many times he wanted to die. In fact, he had asked me to assist him which unfortunately I was not able to do.

I called in to see him on my way to Canberra and he was obviously in pain. He could only nod his head in one direction. When the doctor was called the doctor ascertained he was in pain. He was fitted with a morphine pump to ease the pain. I know that the doctor knew that that pump was going to end his life and I know that the doctor knew I knew. Nothing was said, but it was clearly an understanding. The morphine suppressed the capacity to breath and he passed away peacefully and hopefully in less pain.

What we are dealing with here is not some revolutionary concept. It is quite clear that many people make this determination that it is best for them. If we are going to talk about dignity, the dignity of the individual must be paramount. I think the safeguards in this bill are perfectly adequate. It may be that there are some abuses of it. Why there should be is beyond me, because there are abuses of the present system now. There are some people whose death is hastened I am sure, for whatever reason. But in most cases I think the doctors and nurses who do this do it with the utmost compassion. We are not giving any more chances for this to occur, in fact we are probably reducing the probability of that happening.

I do not know why this has to be an argument between palliative care and the right to die. It seems to me that both are important. I believe very strongly that government should be massively increasing support for palliative care. One of the things I find amusing is that many of the people who have taken part in this debate, and have taken a very strong view in opposing euthanasia, would be the very same people who would oppose the legalisation of the use of heroin in palliative care treatment. There is absolutely no doubt, as experience in the United Kingdom shows, that heroin is a far better substance for relieving pain and keeping people cognisant at the same time than other drugs, particularly morphine. So diamorphine is certainly more effective in this regard, yet many of the people who talk about their opposition to euthanasia, for whatever reasons, are the same people who would actually inhibit the use of the drugs that do make palliative care an alternative option.

I believe that, if people are happy with palliative care, every facility should be put in there for palliative care. We should increase the funding. It is not well funded now. The facilities for it are not widespread and are not well enough available. Certainly, with medical science now, there is probably no need for people to live in pain if they do have access to that palliative care, but it is not widely enough available and that has to be faced. I suggest that people who oppose this bill should go out on a campaign to increase funding for palliative care. They would have my entire support were they to do so.

There are circumstances where people feel that the best way out for their loved ones is to end that suffering. I know this was a consideration of my brother's. He knew the burden he was putting on his wife and, to a lesser extent, the rest of his family—but certainly his wife. The courage and the cheerfulness with which she accepted that task was tremendous. But he knew the burden he had become and he saw no point in prolonging it. He simply wanted out, and I believe he should have had the opportunity. He may not have taken it. In the end he worked out some reconciliation between himself and his God, I guess, and he passed away in relative comfort with the aid of the doctor.

There is absolutely no doubt—and I have spoken to many nurses who worked in this field who say it is very common—that there are situations where patients have begged them, and they have not been able to oblige, but eventually the doctor has acquiesced, for sufficient morphine to be given to make sure that death occurred. This is, in my view, a compassionate situation. Can anyone tell me: what is there to gain, for people in a terminally ill condition, in surviving a little longer?

It has been noted that euthanasia is not accepted generally in the world. We are told it is not a lack of compassion. I do not think it is. It is simply a lack of courage. What the bill simply does is to return some very small power to people. It gives people the option of making a decision for themselves. It does not give power to other people to make options for them as occurs at the moment and, in that sense, it is much more likely to circumvent the convenient death than by simply not having it.

I resent this bill very strongly. We have a very heavy schedule in this parliament. We do not need this legislation. It clearly circumvents the will of the people of the Northern Territory and the people of the Northern Territory have the absolute power to change this at their next election if they feel strongly about it. I doubt whether they will because I, like every member of this parliament, have had mail from people on this issue. My office has been flooded with mail from the people with vested interests, religious concerns and people who write to you with their own personal convictions.

I have been rather interested at the very large proportion of older women that have written to me. It seems to me that in society there may be more toughness or more intellectual rigour in women than occurs in men. Because overwhelmingly the letters I have had are from older women saying, `I want this right. I want this ability to make this decision for myself.' I do not believe the legislation will be overwhelmingly used. I think you will find there will be a few cases a year, because most will leave it too late and many will be accommodated by obliging and compassionate doctors or nurses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pyne, Chris, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Like many members in this House, I have been lobbied from all sides on this matter. Many people have offered well‐considered arguments both for and against the bill and good reasons why I should support their own view. I have of course listened to all of them, but in the end the decision we all have to make is for one side or the other in this argument.

SPEECH.PARA: In this case, Mr Deputy Speaker, I surely do not want to sit on the fence. So let me say at the outset that I support the Andrews bill. Many will no doubt be surprised that as a Liberal my views will not support the freedom—as they would put it—to die with dignity. Others will dismiss my arguments as they will believe my support for this bill is because I am a Catholic. Actually, my religion explains little about my feelings on this issue. Anybody who knows Catholics will know that, while united somewhat by religious faith, we are otherwise a diverse group who because of our creed, not despite it, hold many disparate beliefs on matters less spiritual.

I support the Andrews bill because I believe that active voluntary euthanasia is wrong. Active voluntary euthanasia is not providing relief for pain that hastens death or withholding or withdrawing treatment that is futile or unwanted. Active voluntary euthanasia is where medical intervention is sought by a patient in order to end their own life. I support the Andrews bill because the Northern Territory legislation is poor legislation and could lead to passive involuntary euthanasia where a third party requests the withholding of treatment or, worse still, active voluntary euthanasia where, at the request of a third person, medical intervention takes place to end a life.

In the Netherlands, active euthanasia without the consent of patients and its legislature is being practised now. The Remmelink Committee reported that in 1990 nearly 15,000 had, without their consent, had treatment withdrawn or applied with the intent to terminate their lives. Initially, when the Netherlands law was first enacted, it was felt the controls were sufficient. Now, nearly 20 per cent of all the deaths that occur in the Netherlands are by euthanasia. Over half of those, therefore, are without their consent. Experience in the Netherlands shows that where you have voluntary assisted suicide or euthanasia, involuntary euthanasia will occur—not may, but will, occur. Inevitably, one will follow the other.

There are many legislatures around the globe that have debated voluntary death as a solution for suffering. Every one of those, other than the Northern Territory, has rejected that solution. That does not imply that to be the first is necessarily to be wrong, but to be the first means that you have a greater responsibility to be right, especially in this case where it is a matter of life and death. In courts of law, juries convict in criminal cases only if there is a unanimous feeling that the state has proven its case beyond reasonable doubt. This rush to judgment by the Northern Territory legislature achieved no such unanimity. Now it seems that some who opposed the legislation are willing to support it because it achieved a mere majority, like a juror who holds the accused to be innocent but is nonetheless willing to convict him anyway.

The Northern Territory legislation is not right. It is totally flawed. Its intent is the relief of pain and suffering; but palliative care can relieve much of this. In the Northern Territory, however, where they have passed this legislation, there is no medical oncologist, no palliative care specialist, a barely resourced domiciliary palliative care program, virtually no radiotherapy services and not a single hospice. To many in the Northern Territory it is not surprising that death seems to be the only form of relief.

BREAK.PARA: Some have suggested that this lack of services is justification for euthanasia. To quote some other people, Bill Hayden, our former Governor‐General, told the Royal Australasian College of Physicians that `there is a point when the succeeding generations deserve to be disencumbered of some unproductive burdens.' As another academic and political candidate put it a few years ago, `When you're ripe, it's time to go!' I cannot believe that we are ready to treat human life as we would rotten fruit.

There is a respect for life in our society that is fundamental to all. Respect for the aged, for our parents, for our grandparents, for the mentally ill and for the disabled is common in all societies. We do not grade human beings by their worth, because we believe that we are all equal. We do not place use‐by date stickers on human beings, because we all do contribute to our society, in whatever form. By allowing euthanasia, you necessarily diminish the rights of others by indicating to those that remain that they are a burden; that they are costing too much; that life is not so important after all; and that it can be given away by society because other people have done so.

To take away a life, Mr Deputy Speaker, is the most heinous and serious act punishable by law, not only in our society but in every society throughout the world. We revile those who murder and reserve our most serious sentences for them, not only in our Western civilisation, but in every civilisation throughout the world. We also pour massive resources into saving lives. To accept euthanasia compromises those attitudes and actions. In a society that values life above all other things, it is an incomprehensible about‐face. The New South Wales Voluntary Euthanasia Society long ago made that about‐face, and continued further down the track. Recent attempts to bring euthanasia legislation into effect in New South Wales saw the society urging the inclusion of disability as well as illness in the guidelines to the law.

If you believe that euthanasia, if allowed to remain legal, is totally voluntary then consider the thoughts of Peter Singer, the Melbourne euthanasia advocate, who suggests that babies may be killed up to the age of one month. The Remmelink study shows that there are numbers of handicapped newborns, sick children and psychiatric and AIDS patients whose lives were terminated by doctors. Euthanasia proponents say that this is about the right to die. I believe it is more about the right to be killed by someone else. It is less about easing the pain of dying than it is about making death more palatable for surviving relatives.
Euthanasia proponents believe that doctors should become killers. The Hippocratic oath states:
If any shall ask of me a drug to produce death, I will not give it, nor will I suggest such counsel.
Euthanasia proponents expect doctors to abandon the centuries-old ethics of that profession. The Australian Medical Association's code of ethics, recently updated, says of dying patients:
Always bear in mind the obligation of preserving life, but allow death to occur with dignity and comfort, where death is deemed to be inevitable and where curative treatment appears to be futile.

Euthanasia proponents expect doctors to ignore that too. As the son of an eye surgeon, Mr Deputy Speaker, I was brought up in the belief that doctors are trained to heal, not to kill. Relieving pain that hastens death or withdrawing unwanted treatment is not intentional killing. Administering a lethal injection is.

There has also been an attempt in this debate by proponents of euthanasia to turn this into an issue of state rights. To acquiesce to bad law and wrong principles by hiding behind a facile argument that is patently flawed, which even a cursory glance at the Australian constitution will prove, would be extremely cowardly. The Commonwealth clearly has the power to act in this case. Some have dismissed the attempt to do so as blatant paternalism. I suppose those voices would also be raised when a parent confiscated dangerous drugs from their 18‐year‐old son or daughter, calling that blatant paternalism, too. In closing, I should state that I cannot in all good conscience oppose a bill that I know, if passed, will save the lives of Australian people. I urge the House to support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mossfield, Frank, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking in support of the bill proposed by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews). In doing so, I am sure that members on both sides of the debate are motivated by the desire to ease the pain and discomfort of dying people. Provided that sufficient government finance is available, we should expect continued advancement in this field of medical science. However, people who are promoting euthanasia would not be as strong in their conviction for improved palliative care as would those who see this form of care as the best means of assisting terminally ill people.

SPEECH.PARA: While we are all upset about the suffering that individual people like Mr Dent have experienced, we should consider what harmful effects euthanasia could have on society and, in fact, question if there would be an increase in involuntary euthanasia. There is some evidence to suggest that this would be the case.

Listening to ABC Radio on the evening of 26 September, I heard two supporters of euthanasia make statements that concerned me. I believe they give some insight into post-voluntary euthanasia Australia. Mr Jeff Kennett said, in part:

The Northern Territory have taken a very courageous leadership role, and I think most of us, probably if faced with a year, two years, three years, 20 years of incredible pain and we made that decision to exit with grace, we should be allowed to do so.

Would Mr Kennett be suggesting with this time frame that people would be encouraged to exit with grace at an early stage of their illness? This would deny the opportunity of the medical profession to develop a cure or develop treatment that would make that person's life comfortable. Michael Baume said, on the same program:
There are over 7000 doctors in Australia today who admit to having practised euthanasia at least once and I believe some of these have been non‐voluntary.

If Michael Baume is correct and non‐voluntary euthanasia has been practised in Australia when voluntary euthanasia is illegal, it is in itself a very frightening thought. But how much more widely practised would it become if voluntary euthanasia were legal?

The Australian Labor Party allows a conscience vote on moral and ethical issues such as euthanasia. As with most moral issues, Australian people would have a wide variety of views. In this particular case, these would relate to constitutional issues as well as social and moral questions. My personal view is that it is morally wrong for the state to take a life or for the state to legislate to assist in taking a human life.

What I believe is at stake here is the value of human life. If we cheapen the value of life in any way, but particularly by legislation, we would open the door for other forms of termination of life in circumstances other than what is proposed on this occasion. In Australia we have seen criminal elements show scant regard for life. In many overseas countries we have seen the same disregard for life for political and territorial reasons.

While some have raised the state rights question, there seems to be a serious flaw in this argument when the first publicised person who was to enact the legislation resided in another state. As the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act is available to all Australians, it is therefore appropriate for the federal parliament to debate this issue.

BREAK.PARA: I have received considerable correspondence on this issue, as I know all members have, from within my own electorate and from throughout Australia. I certainly thank those within my electorate who have taken the time to let me know their views. But this national interest justifies the federal parliament expressing a national opinion. In my view, the issue of appropriate palliative care and the continued need for medical research to find cures for major illnesses goes hand in hand with my opposition to euthanasia.

In this modern economic world, there is a continual battle to obtain sufficient funds to finance health and care facilities for those most in need, whether they be in need of child care, medical services for families, care for people with disabilities or elderly people. It should be remembered that a long and relatively comfortable life is available for many people with major medical problems, thanks to progress in medical science and services. With improved medical research we could save the lives of patients where they were thought to be terminally ill at one point. If the argument were accepted that euthanasia was valid in terminating the life of one person, it would clearly place under threat the lives of many other people who society considers, for medical reasons, may just as well be dead.

My view on this point is supported by Dr Carlos Gomez from the University of Virginia Hospital in Charlottesville, Virginia, who carried out the research for his doctoral thesis on 26 cases of euthanasia in the Netherlands. While the majority of the patients appeared to meet the criteria for euthanasia, in at least four cases they did not, according to Dr Gomez's research. In one case, a doctor injected a lethal dose of potassium chloride into someone who had been severely injured in a car accident and looked unlikely to recover. The doctor wanted to spare the family the emotional suffering.

Another case quoted by Dr Gomez was the killing of a two‐year‐old child with Down syndrome. The child would probably have lived for 40 or 50 years. Dr Gomez has said that, in Holland, you feel that something is going on behind the argument for patients' autonomy. He said that some physicians think that certain patients are better off dead than alive and they are willing to make that decision.Surely we, as a society, do not want to close the door on continual research into what are now seen as incurable diseases. Do we want to close the door on continuing to care for ourselves and our family members as we grow older? I believe euthanasia would place these obligations on our society under threat. All major political parties have agreed that society has an obligation to provide medical care for all sections of our community, particularly those unable to help themselves: the young and the elderly. Governments have an obligation to ensure that modern medicine is available to relieve the pain of dying people; that good palliative care is available to ensure the control of pain and provide around‐the‐clock support to relieve the emotional distress of dying patients and their families.

There is clearly a political and economic side being argued by some in this debate. If we find finance is not sufficient to supply adequate medical services to the general public, then quick‐fix solutions are going to be seen as possible options. I believe it is necessary in opposing euthanasia to also ensure that the medical profession and care service providers have the necessary funds to provide palliative care for the terminally ill and aged members of our society. Therefore, I would urge the coalition government and Labor opposition to support additional funding for the care of aged and ill members of our society.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I have sat down on many occasions to think and to write a few lines about my decision to oppose euthanasia. I have read many letters that I have received from constituents and beyond. I have read letters from famous people, professionals in the field of medicine and ordinary people in the street. Having considered the views put to me, both in correspondence and by personal representations, my conscience tells me that euthanasia is morally wrong. My main concern is that we are trying to interfere with our culture. Some other societies may practise a form of euthanasia but this has never been the path of Australian society. Our culture has been to preserve life; to look after the elderly, people with disabilities, people who are mentally ill and the young.

BREAK.PARA: If euthanasia were accepted into the law of this country at any level, we would be placing terrible pressure on many of these people, and on the medical profession to terminate human life ahead of its time, as well as removing our clear responsibility to provide public funding to continue to improve our health services.
