There would be less need to provide finance to encourage medical research into finding cures for major illnesses such as cancer, AIDS and Alzheimer's disease. There would be less need to provide finance for nursing homes to provide comfort, care and pain relief for dying people. But, worst of all, we would be opening the door to a callous, less caring society. We would be opening the door to the unknown if we accept any form of euthanasia. It is extremely likely that at the healthy community's convenience other forms of mercy killing or genocide would follow, as it has in other countries, from pre‐war Germany to post‐war Holland.

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 11.55 a.m. to 12.10 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I intend to conclude my speech with a quote from John Donne:

BREAK.PARA: Any man's death diminishes me, because I am involved in Mankind; And therefore never send to know for whom the bell tolls; it tolls for thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zammit, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I state my position at the outset. I am opposed to voluntary euthanasia on two major and specific grounds: that is, on religious, moral grounds and because of the unsolvable legal intricacies. I oppose euthanasia because of my deeply held religious and moral conviction as one who adheres to Christian beliefs and places absolute value on the sanctity of life. In fact, not only the Christian faith but also all the other major world religions have at least one tenet in common, and that is respect for the absolute sanctity of life. Voluntary euthanasia contravenes that sanctity. The second major and specific ground for my opposition to euthanasia relates to the impossibility of putting to paper the legal requirements that will not be open to widespread abuse.

SPEECH.PARA: I am acutely aware of my responsibilities as a legislator, having served 12 years in the New South Wales parliament and about eight months in the federal parliament, in ensuring that laws are not enacted that are open to abuse, either deliberately or in all innocence, whether it be perceived or otherwise. The Northern Territory legislation on voluntary euthanasia is abhorrent to me because of at least two reasons, as I mentioned earlier, the former relating to moral grounds and the latter because it is unworkable legislation. I will expand on that later in my speech.

Three arguments have been promoted by the supporters of euthanasia in support of their case against the deliberations of this parliament. It is their assertion that states rights are being violated, that the issue is not one for the federal parliament, and that rather it should be determined by referendum and we should mirror the views of the alleged majority as reflected in opinion polls that show overwhelming support for euthanasia. My response to that assertion is that I am a federalist and a member of the federal parliament which represents all Australians. We, as federal members of parliament, simply cannot avoid this debate which has Australia‐wide implications. We are not a regional or narrow parliament, and it is certainly not a states rights issue as it is the indisputable right of the Commonwealth parliament to make laws for any state or territory under section 122 of the Commonwealth constitution.

The second argument by the supporters of euthanasia refers to the matter of a referendum to decide the issue. The electorate expects us, as its elected representatives, to show leadership and shoulder our responsibilities. It certainly does not want us to shirk our obligations every time an issue arises, no matter how contentious and/or potentially divisive it may prove to be, by dispatching it to referendum. A people's referendum must only be used to determine changes to the Australian constitution. It must never be used by parliaments to avoid taking responsibility for matters other than for constitutional changes.

The third argument refers to the matter of the alleged majority view as determined by opinion polls. I strongly reject the view that parliaments should be poll driven. Our future as parliamentarians is determined by the people every three or so years based on our performance, our accessibility to our constituents and the views we expound—and that is the way it should be. I will nonetheless make passing reference to the issue of opinion polling, especially and in particular to this most complex and contentious of issues, that of euthanasia.

How can such a complex issue, with moral conscience overtones, with legalistic difficulties and with potentially unforeseen legislative ramifications, be responded to by a simplistic yes or no response? The fact is that it can not. Additionally, the wording of the question put to those who are polled can lead to differing interpretations unless time is spent explaining the background and the detailed arguments for and against so that a proper judgmental opinion can be given.

Having now spoken to many people and having received a very large number of letters on this subject over many years, I am convinced that the average person thinks of the issue of euthanasia as simply a matter of turning off the machine. It is little wonder then that an overwhelming number of people are supportive of euthanasia as they would define it. The fact is that that definition could not be further from the truth.

Euthanasia is not turning off a machine that results in someone's death. Euthanasia is not about giving a person a pain killer which might lower that person's resistance levels which may result in an accelerated death. Euthanasia is the administering of a lethal injection, an injection administered by a fellow human being, that results in an instantaneous, premeditated killing.

Spokespeople for all the major religions have spoken out against voluntary euthanasia and have spoken out not only with the authority of the scriptures and holy teachings that are unchanged through the ages. The position taken by the religious—that is, the Christians and those who follow the holy Torah, the holy Mosaic law, those who follow the teaching of the Koran, the Buddhists, the Hindus and all the other major religions—places the utmost emphasis on the sanctity of life. God gives and God takes.

The second major reason for the authority by which the religious speak on this issue is the fact that the religious have spent, and continue to spend, a huge amount of their resources in the form of not only personnel but also substantial sums of money in providing support for the dying and the families of the dying. In fact, a cursory glance at a comparison of the resources provided by the religious and the state towards the terminally ill shows a very heavy bias towards the religious. Therefore, if for no other reason, we have to listen to what the religious are warning against in regard to voluntary euthanasia, as they probably know, more than anyone else, that these unacceptable moral and legal obstacles exist that are insurmountable and therefore must be strenuously opposed.

Additionally, the non‐religious based support groups and associations, including the RSL, that minister to those who are terminally ill are all—with the exception of only one association—opposed to voluntary euthanasia. The association that stands alone is called the Coalition of Organisations for Voluntary Euthanasia. It is interesting to note that one of their policy objectives is that voluntary euthanasia be available to people with disabilities, whether they are terminally ill or not. That policy is strenuously opposed by all the disability groups throughout Australia. In fact, some of the most powerful opponents of voluntary euthanasia are the disability organisations that have played a major role throughout the world when legislators have considered the issue of voluntary euthanasia.

I turn now to the question of the codification, in statute form, of the circumstances under which a human life can be terminated legally and without the possibility of challenges to the law in the courts by relatives of the deceased or by community groups opposed to euthanasia. An undeniable fact has now emerged that no form of words can ever be put into legislation to legalise the circumstances and the safeguards to allow human beings to snuff out the life of another human being. The Northern Territory parliament has attempted to do that. However, their legislation is not only deficient at law but also lacks proper safeguards. For instance, the Northern Territory legislation allows for a two‐day cooling‐off period before life is extinguished. Yet we allow a five‐day cooling‐off period when someone buys a used car. How does the Northern Territory parliament justify that not unreasonable comparison between a human being and a used car?

It has been estimated that some 25,000 Australians could be yearly candidates for voluntary euthanasia. Can anyone seriously claim that each and every one of these cases will be subjected to the same scrutiny and the same safeguards? Will the individual applicants for euthanasia have these safeguards equally applied in each and every case? Or will we as a society become so desensitised to voluntary euthanasia that it will become an everyday occurrence, with a`ho‐hum' attitude becoming the norm?

We have to ensure that all who face a terminal illness will be confident in the fact that their final days will be without the added pressures of a final solution being theirs alone, and that—despite the fact that they feel desperately that they do not want to be a burden on their families—they will not have the option of leaving this world as soon as the law allows so as to not be a burden. If voluntary euthanasia is condoned, how many terminally ill patients will push the button because they may feel that one or more of their relatives want them to do so?

We hear of the unbearable pain and suffering experienced by many terminally ill people being put forward as the main reason for euthanasia. Whilst no‐one can deny that people who are sick all feel varying degrees of pain, the fact is that our focus should always be on reducing the pain threshold and not on extinguishing the life. The overwhelming evidence produced by those who specialise in palliative care demonstrates beyond doubt that, even in the most severe cases, patients—in consultation with their doctors and families—can receive injections of chemical cocktails of various levels of potency to enable them to remain awake or at various levels of consciousness and, if the pain becomes unbearable, to keep them asleep until they die naturally.

There seems little doubt that palliative care is becoming a major issue in our society, with an ageing population. No doubt all governments will have to spend increasing resources on palliative care, especially in ministering to the terminally ill. That is one issue that has to be resolutely addressed, and sooner rather than later. The inescapable fact is that euthanasia involves the taking of human life by another human being. That concept runs counter to all that a civilised society can or should allow, if we are not to gradually descend to the depths of barbarity by reaching for the ultimate in our throw‐away society, throw‐away humans. Voluntary euthanasia is the antithesis of a humane and compassionate society, and must be opposed at every stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman, Alan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This whole debate on the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996 is put in the context of territory rights versus moral rights of the federal parliament to make decisions in these matters. At a point members of the federal parliament have to make a decision on whether the moral rights that are implicit in this decision—so many of our decisions do have a moral aspect to them, whether we like it or not—override the proposals put forward by the Northern Territory. I believe they do. I believe that, apart from the whole states rights issue, there is another dimension, and that is the dimension that is pivotal in the whole process that the parliament is dealing with today.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian parliament has dealt with similar issues of this type. The Tasmanian legislation on the rights of the homosexual community was one of those issues. This is a life and death issue and nothing could be more significant and more pivotal to the existence to our fellow Australians than the matter that we are dealing with today. It goes to the very basis of the delivery of health and the role of doctors and health professionals in our system. It is asking of them to think of themselves in a new dimension. Just to illustrate the process, I want to refer to a useful article provided to members by Karin Clark from Melbourne. Karin Clark goes to the processes of a doctor actually making a decision on what techniques should be best applied if a person wishes to participate in euthanasia. These are the comments by Karin Clark on the Northern Territory legislation:

Section 7(2) provides that a medical practitioner must be guided by `appropriate medical standards' and any prescribed guidelines and must `consider the appropriate pharmaceutical information about any substance reasonably available for use in the circumstances'.
That is the circumstances of euthanasia.
Difficult questions about the liability of the doctor may arise if the chosen combination of drugs is not effective to kill the patient in a `humane' or `dignified' or quick way.

Here we have health professionals whose whole career, whose whole training, is focused on providing and sustaining life, and they are suddenly asked to change their thinking to what is the most appropriate, humane and dignified way that they can deliver death for a person. That switch required in the thinking of our medical professionals will then carry through, if the House supports euthanasia in the Northern Territory, to the whole attitude of our doctors and the medical profession.

It will reach a point ultimately where they are thinking in part, `What is the process I must use in order to bring about a dignified death of this person? What cocktail of drugs must I deliver to bring about a humane and dignified death?' Then patients themselves will start to consider, `Am I at a point yet in my life where the doctor is considering whether they will bring about a dignified and human death, or what drugs could be used to bring those circumstances about?' The whole relationship between doctor and patient changes in a most dreadful way. When you have got a very sick person—they may be terminally ill or they may not be terminally ill—lying there wondering, `How is this doctor going to continue to treat me? Can I continue to trust this person or am I going to get that dreadful question, "Have things gone too far for you?"' To me, that is a whole basic and terrible change in a relationship which must be founded on trust and absolute and complete confidence.

The medical practitioner is granted immunity, under the civil code and under the criminal code, if the medical practitioner acts in good faith and without negligence in compliance with the territory act. So, if they fail in the process of delivering the fatal dose, are they in some way absolved from making that mistake? Are they absolved from making a mistake about killing somebody? What is society playing with here? We expect in the one individual an absolute commitment to the maintenance of life and then absolve them if they fail to deliver a death. To me, that is a terrible conflict that cannot be resolved.

This is about a personal thing, it gets to the very essence of an individual, and in the processes of making this decision it no longer becomes a personal matter. It is not a matter of suicide or a person making a decision to take their own life; immediately other members of that person's family are involved. A whole medical team is also involved by participating to assist them to take a decision about whether they continue to live or not. So it moves far beyond just the personal matter. A person, an individual, has the right to make decisions, a terrible decision though it would be to me if they decided to commit suicide. But we cannot take away that free will from an individual in any way. In fact, many insist on pursuing to the ultimate the decision to take their own lives.

But then, if we can say that this is really only assisted suicide then we try to absolve those people who are asked to participate in the process from any ramifications. We rationalise that they are simply asked to participate in a suicide. There is no judgment for them to make at all, really, because the person suiciding is making an individual decision and that right still rests with them. They are asked to participate in the act whether they want to or not. But I do not believe any individual should ever be confronted to make a decision of that sort about the life of another person.

It is simply not a voluntary process at all that we are looking at. There is no such thing as voluntary euthanasia because as soon as we start to consider the voluntary nature of the thing you start to think about disabled people and infants. Where does the voluntary decision come for disabled people and infants? It becomes an involuntary process. They are no longer asked. You have only to refer to people like Mark Oliphant, who is the patron of the Voluntary Euthanasia Society in South Australia, and who said, in reference to someone he knows, `he should have been dead years ago and he is not; he just loves to be a damn nuisance to his friends and relatives.' Ellen Fanning, who was conducting the interview said, `And that's his right too, isn't it?' Mark responded, `No, I don't think it is. I think he is cluttering up the whole world at a time when he should not'.

How can you have one of Australia's greatest scientists proposing that? He is patron of the South Australian Society for Voluntary Euthanasia. He is not talking about voluntary euthanasia. He is talking about the prospect of getting rid of somebody who is just a damn nuisance cluttering up the place. We cannot have anybody given that power as Sir Mark has expressed it.

BREAK.PARA: I want to conclude by speaking about a very interesting seminar we had last weekend in my district of Castle Hill, where over 200 people attended. We had the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) there and the honourable former Senator Peter Baume. They discussed this issue in a very quiet and civilised way and the audience were very pleased to be able to hear these two men with differing views discuss these important matters. But there is no doubt in my mind of the views of the majority of those people, the great majority. They just thought that this whole process is too risky and too dangerous and they do not want us to pursue it as an Australian nation.

One only has to look at the prospects of determining the definitions. What is a terminal illness? What conditions must be met before euthanasia takes place? You are thinking of codifying this process in law and having it laid down so that it can be tested in the court. What must the patient be suffering to qualify? Who is excluded because of clinical depression? What about mental illnesses other than clinical depression? Who is of sound mind? What other conditions must be met for euthanasia to take place? When is palliative care available? All of these things are factors that are taken into account. I think that to codify those by the process of law is impossible.

Finally, I think of one man I know, John Temple. When John was five, his parents were advised to let him die. Just five years ago, John won the Order of Australia for his contribution to disabled people. Bob Hawke was delighted to honour this man for his contribution and so were the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party. Yet here was a man, who has lived a most substantial life, whose parents were told, `Let him die.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr, Duncan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate on the Euthanasia Laws Bill has brought forward some of the most compassionate and best thought out contributions to parliamentary debate that I have witnessed in the nine years I have been a member. Might I say at the outset that I do still regard it as a matter of considerable regret that this debate is occurring in the forum of the Main Committee rather than in the House, where members would have been more able to participate and certainly the Australian public would have had a greater opportunity of seeing the people that they have elected to office participate genuinely in deciding one of the great issues that have emerged. Members in this debate are faced with an issue of conscience and will exercise a deliberative vote upon an issue where neither party has directed their votes.

SPEECH.PARA: I too have given anxious consideration to this bill. My starting point was other than suggested by the mover of this resolution. My starting point, as I have explained to many who have spoken to me about this issue, was that, essentially, individuals have residing within themselves faculties of will and self‐determination which should not be overridden by the state.

When I was considering how to vote in relation to this matter, however, a number of arguments were put to me which made me reflect upon that starting position. The most telling of those arguments was advanced to me not by one of the more public of lobbyists but by Senator Harradine, who I think in the public forums has been relatively quiet, although his views are well known.

Senator Harradine spoke to me on a plane, travelling back to Hobart. He said that his principal concern was that some amongst the elderly who find themselves in situations where they feel somewhat of a burden to their families—they may find themselves in nursing homes or in some circumstance where they identify themselves as no longer being necessary to the wellbeing of their families but, perhaps, causing them some burden, some additional responsibilities—will be forced to think about a question which ought not be put to them. Indeed, they may be placed in a position where a matter that ought not have to come before them inevitably is drawn to their attention and, therefore, what for some of us in the community will be an act of willed choice will be asked of them in circumstances where that act of willed choice has not been sought.

That is a powerful argument to reflect on. Nonetheless it struck me, on thinking further on it, that such elderly persons and others in such circumstances already reflect upon that choice as the law presently stands. They reflect upon it and, should they decide to request assistance for their death, they do so notwithstanding that that choice currently is not available under the law. And they already find within medical practitioners a substantial group of doctors who are willing to facilitate the execution of that choice.

I understand that surveys within the Australian Medical Association show a very substantial minority of doctors are prepared currently to accede to requests under limited circumstances where they accept that the patient is suffering terminal pain and has rationally thought out their decision to bring their life to an end and do make available that assistance. We do not treat such doctors as murderers; our society does not do that. If we did then doctors who self-admittedly have carried out such procedures would be investigated by police, but they are not.

For example, within our own ranks, Dr Brendan Nelson, surprisingly a proponent of the Andrews bill, says that he himself has twice carried out active voluntary euthanasia. How can it be that somebody who asserts their right as a doctor, contrary to the law as it currently stands, can come before this parliament and say that that choice should not be available legally to patients who seek it under very restricted circumstances?

One of the most eloquent contributions to this debate I have found came from the Mercury editorial, my own home newspaper. I rarely refer to the Mercury editorials, they are rarely so eloquent. They comment usually on local political events. However, the editorialist of 30 October found voice for sentiments that put this situation as well as I have ever read. The editorialist referred to the different arguments and said:
The points made for and against are salient. They are made by people with strong convictions. They are points which are deserving of respect.

Yet the most relevant point, the one which many of the politicians involved in the debate in Federal Parliament acknowledge, and the one which the moralists and ethicists who decry euthanasia cannot ignore, is the one involving personal freedom.

People choose how they will live. They cannot be denied the right, once life becomes so unpleasant, so full of pain and misery that it is devoid of any semblance of what it had been, to choose how and when to die.
There are counter-arguments that adequate safeguards cannot be devised to prevent a system which allows euthanasia from being abused.
This is probably correct. Loopholes will be found.

But will they be any greater than the `loophole' which now sees blind eyes being turned to the fact that euthanasia, by any other name, is now being committed, without any legal safeguards and on a regular basis?

That is a very compelling case. We, as a society, currently turn a blind eye to euthanasia being committed regularly but without the safeguards that the Northern Territory legislation provides. I cannot see how it can be said to be moral to turn that blind eye and then to deny to the parliament of the Northern Territory a process that provides extremely restrictive guidelines for the exercise of that moral choice.

BREAK.PARA: It does seem to me that there is a greater likelihood of abuse not occurring, of people's will not being overborne, if euthanasia has to be carried out within a legal framework. It strikes me that it is more probable than not that those doctors who currently carry out euthanasia in a circumstance where society is turning a blind eye are not referring to all the safeguards that are required in the Northern Territory legislation and they are not required to seek the independent testimony of psychiatrists and other specialists. They take it upon themselves, as part of their responsibility to the care of that patient, to exercise an individual judgment which they know will not be second‐guessed by anyone. It is more likely than not that euthanasia would be less common were states and territories to apply strict guidelines so that anything that takes itself outside of those guidelines is genuinely treated as murder, is genuinely treated as a crime against society.

I believe that we are in a false and hypocritical environment if we acknowledge as a society that these things occur but apply to those people no moral opprobrium for breaking those laws or for transgressing the moral framework which we assert. The most obvious example of that is Dr Nelson, a member of this parliament, who supports the Andrews bill yet has himself admitted to two instances of active euthanasia, and perhaps more passive instances, in the conduct of his own medical practice.

After anxious thought and with respect to people like Margaret Tighe, who is present and who has spoken to me, and to Senator Harradine and many others who I believe have come into this debate with passionately held views, my conclusion is that this measure should be opposed. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We are participating today in the national parliament—albeit in this chamber, we are still in the national parliament—in a debate about the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996. This is a very important debate. It is a debate about `death'. It is a debate about whether we, as Australians, accept the practice of one human actively—I underline `actively'—and intentionally killing another human being who decides they no longer wish to live.

SPEECH.PARA: While public debate about this topic has raged over recent months, one thing is clear—that is, within our community there are very widely held and often very strong views about `death'. This diversity of opinion has been reflected in the many letters and faxes on this issue that I have received. Our views about `death' are most often shaped by personal experience, and it is easy to get caught up amongst the emotive arguments for and against euthanasia. But our responsibility as national law makers, as elected politicians, is to try to examine this issue as clinically and factually as possible.

Firstly, the Commonwealth parliament is the appropriate forum for such a debate. Whether intentionally or not, the Northern Territory's Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995 does affect all Australians. Attempts by Chief Minister Stone to limit the effect of the Northern Territory bill to Territorians are only farcical. Since this debate came on in this House, we have seen moves in the media by the particular doctor that has already undertaken to euthanase one person in the Northern Territory, encouraging more people to come to the Northern Territory and get the relevant certificates if they want to be euthanased as well.

Secondly, this is not an issue about states rights. The Andrews bill seeks to use the Commonwealth's legitimate constitutional powers to override a territory law. This bill is not revolutionary but follows the proper conventions of our constitution, under section 122. It is a pity that the member for Denison (Mr Kerr) has just left, because I heard one of the Labor Party members comment this morning that he thought that the coalition was all about support for states rights. They have short memories, Mr Deputy Speaker. When we voted on a bill that had an effect on individuals' rights in Tasmania, as you would recall, almost the majority of coalition members—in opposition as we were then—voted in support of individuals' rights over and above the rights of the state. That is what this debate is all about.

Australians already have the right to die. Many states, and the Northern Territory, have legislation that gives people the right to refuse medical treatment even if the treatment would prolong or save their life. However, the Northern Territory's Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995 goes one step further by allowing a doctor to prescribe, prepare or administer a substance to a patient with the intention of bringing about death. In this context the right to die really means the right to be killed on request.

Experience in the Netherlands has demonstrated all too clearly that the practice of euthanasia is profoundly corrupting and ultimately uncontrollable. Euthanasia remains a criminal offence in the Netherlands, but it has been openly practised for some years on the premise that doctors act in accordance with a number of formal criteria which have been enshrined in legislation. I disagree with the previous speaker that it should be codified so that there are controls on the doctors. We have seen in so many law making practices in this nation that codifying something—codifying a moral issue, codifying moral guidelines—provides, in reverse, the parameters for people to argue legally in a court to do something rather than not to do it. I do not believe that in this instance codification is what is required morally in this country.

The guidelines for euthanasia are supposed to be limited to those who have a serious physical illness and who make a voluntary request for euthanasia. However, there is ample evidence that these guidelines have been flouted. Dr John Keown, lecturer in medical ethics at Cambridge University, recently stated in a letter to the Age:
. . . the Dutch experience provides weighty evidence of the `slippery slope' from killing on request to killing without request.
And that is my argument about codifying the moral ethics of this issue. Further, Dr Keown said:

The (Dutch) guidelines require a free well‐considered request for euthanasia by the patient, but it is disputed that thousands of Dutch patients have been killed without request, and courts recently upheld the killing of disabled babies.
The guidelines limit euthanasia to cases of `unbearable suffering', but this has been held to include depression.
The guidelines require euthanasia to be a `last resort', but good palliative care is widely unavailable.

The guidelines require doctors to report all cases of euthanasia to the authorities but one survey revealed that over 70% were not and were instead illegally certified by doctors as death by `natural causes'.

Even more alarming was the Chabot decision of the Dutch courts in which a woman with no physical illness, but a history of psychiatric illness, requested a lethal dose from her doctor after her husband walked out and her two sons had died. The courts held that she was an appropriate person for euthanasia, even though her mental `suffering' was derived from non‐physical causes.

Despite assurances of appropriate guidelines and safeguards within the Northern Territory bill, how can we guarantee that non‐voluntary euthanasia will not occur? As the member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) has suggested:

BREAK.PARA: How can you police a system of safeguards when every time the safeguards are breached, the only witness is dead?
As a world first, the Northern Territory bill raises a number of perplexing issues.

How can we improve standards of palliative care if the solution is euthanasia? Critics of palliative care say it is degrading and does not provide pain relief in certain circumstances. But how can we improve current practice if we kill the patient? What about the pressures on health care providers, such as nurses? While the Northern Territory act states that no health care provider is under any duty to participate in euthanasia, what is to say they will not feel pressured to assist or face from within the medical hierarchy?

How do we safeguard against an act of non‐voluntary euthanasia? The Dutch experience shows guidelines do not work. A doctor's diagnosis or prognosis about a person's terminal illness can be wrong. There are many examples where patients with terminal illnesses have defied their prognosis and gone on to live fulfilling lives. Does legalising euthanasia pressure other people to end their lives? Making death an acceptable and legal solution to problems could pressure people, young or old, into taking this action—for example, increasing youth suicide or turning nursing homes into `death camps'.

Can the Northern Territory legislation be contained? There are genuine fears from disabled groups and others within the community that this legislation signals a devaluing of the lives of people who may be intellectually or physically disabled. As members of the human race, we must have an intrinsic belief in the special worth of human life—individually and personally I do. I have been present at the birth of all three of my children and I have a very deep belief in the worth of human life.

I do not believe that any human being has the right to take life away from another. It is the fundamental value on which all others are based and is the foundation of both law and medical practice. I refer to the words of the previous speaker, the member for Denison, with regard to medical practice. When doctors take the Hippocratic oath they are committed for their professional lives to saving lives and prolonging life, not snuffing it out, not euthanasing people. Legalising euthanasia attacks the very basis of our society.

I have no hesitation in supporting this bill. In closing, I will refer to a few comments from my constituents in the electorate of Lyne. Overwhelmingly, the correspondence that has come into my office from my constituents has been against the Northern Territory legislation and in favour of the legislation that we are debating here today. They say that it is a national issue and that, as the elected representatives of the federal parliament, we have a responsibility to make a decision about it and to let our community know where we stand.

The overwhelming majority of correspondence I have received from my electorate has been in favour of the so‐called `Andrews bill' to strike down the Northern Territory bill. This is not about states rights. It is about individual rights. We voted on an issue like this once before and the coalition also voted with the Labor Party then. This is a conscience vote, and I support the bill being proposed by the member for Menzies. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would prefer it if we were not having this debate because, as good as palliative care now is, and despite the fact that death is already hastened by the injection of pain‐killing drugs, there is no doubt that some people experience unacceptably prolonged periods of pain. It does not sit easily with me that my decision to support this private member's bill will affect some of those people.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

BREAK.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 20 August 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answers to questions Nos 23, 24 and 25 (Hansard , 20 August 1996, pages 3263‐5), are records kept by government‐owned business enterprises (GBEs) of shareholdings in overseas or unlisted Australian business enterprises.
(2) Is his Department responsible for monitoring the shareholdings, propriety and suitability of overseas businesses in which GBEs invest; if not, who is.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) keeps records of its shareholdings in the unlisted Australian business entities Airport Fine Foods Pty Limited, Airports Australia Pty Limited and FAC Investments Pty Limited (as shown in the Corporation's annual reports). ANL Limited keeps records (as required under the Corporations Law) of its shareholdings in a number of unlisted Australian and overseas business entities (as shown in the Line's annual reports). The Australian National Railways Commission and Airservices Australia do not hold shares.
(2) Yes, for portfolio GBEs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 21 August 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the case of Mrs Edna Bruce of St Marys, NSW and her late husband, a former employee of his department at St Marys.
(2) Was Mr Bruce offered a voluntary redundancy package; if so, when.

(3) If a voluntary redundancy package was offered, is he able to say whether Mr Bruce (a) was sick at the time, and if so; for how long had he been sick and (b) had been advised by his physician that his case was terminal.
(4) Under which Award was Mr Bruce employed.
(5) Did his Award allow either the Department or Mr Bruce to shorten or waive the 28 day period for the notice and retirement to take effect.
(6) Was any consideration given by his Department to shortening the 28 day period, given Mr Bruce's poor health.
(7) Was counselling arranged for Mr Bruce to ensure he was able to exercise his rights to accept the voluntary redundancy package immediately; if not, why not.
(8) When did Mr Bruce die.
(9) Has Mrs Bruce requested an act of grace payment; if so, has the payment been agreed to.
(10) If Mrs Bruce's act of grace payment has not been agreed to, why not.

(11) Has advice been provided that agreeing to this request would create a dangerous precedent; if so, how many instances exist of a public servant accepting a voluntary redundancy package but dying before it came into effect.
(12) What would have been the cost to the Commonwealth of act of grace payments to the families referred to in part (11) since 1986 if those payments had been approved.
(13) Is he satisfied with his Department's conduct in this case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: — The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes. On 25 January 1990 with redundancy date of effect being 28 February 1990, following Mr Bruce's expression of interest in late November 1989.
(3)(a) Yes. On the basis of medical certificates received, since 6 November 1988;
(b) Not known. Medical certificates covering early 1990 identified a different illness from that reported in 1988/89. No prognosis was contained in the certificates.
(4) Storeman and Packers' General Stores (Australian Government Employment) Award 1986 (translated from Determination No. 114 of 1951).
(5) The voluntary redundancy offer was made under the provisions of the Australian Public Service Redeployment and Retirement (Redundancy) Award.
A 28 day notice period under the Award can be shortened if requested by the employee or if directed by the employer. Neither request nor direction occurred.
(6) No record of any such consideration exists.
(7) Notification to all staff being offered voluntary redundancy included advice that "where the 28 day notice period is foreshortened, either by direction mentioned above or by your request".

Mr Bruce's election for voluntary redundancy noted his understanding that retirement could take place at any time within the notice period and also that it was likely that the retirement would take effect from 20 February 1990.
Departmental records do not cover whether Mr Bruce was counselled or not about the date of effect.
(8) 14 February 1990.
(9) Yes; no.

(10) Act of Grace payments are administered by the Department of Finance. Since the initial request in early 1990, successive Ministers for Finance have considered and affirmed the decision five times.
(11) No; the precedential and inequitable aspects of special treatment in this case has been the subject of interdepartmental correspondence; not known as central records would not be kept.
(12) Not known.

(13) Yes; the Department of Administrative Services has administered the redundancy provisions in accordance with the relevant Awards, and referred the request for an Act of Grace payment to relevant authority for determination.
